questions.question_text:
What is the expected output of the following code?
//IMG//

comments.content:
Because during an assignment, the RHS is evaluated first and the result is assignment to the given identifier. In this case, the `x` on the RHS was a function and the result (1 + x() = 1 + 2) was REASSIGNED/BOUND to the same identifier. Post reassignment, x is bound to a int literal, while before it was bound to a function.

I hope this snippet will help: https://prnt.sc/u1u8ki

discussion.content: I know we shouldn't use function name same as variable name. But if I run the code the result is 3. Why?

Selected Answer: D
Selected Answer: D

Selected Answer: D
def x(): #x_function
 return 2
x=1+x() #x_value=use x_function
print(x) #-->3

def x(): #x_function
 return 2
x=10 #x_value=int
x=1+x() #x_value=use not exist x_function
print(x) #-->TypeError: 'int' object is not callable
D.prints 3

Selected Answer: D
D. print 3

def x(i):
 print(i)
 return i
x=x(1)+x(2)
Expression is evaluated from left to right, function return takes more precedence then followed by operator and finally value is assigned which is of least precedence. Above example would illustrate it.

comments.content: It works for me even is i and I, check my code up

the capital I would cause an error if you were to iterate through actual generator obj, for example in [for i in f(2)] there would be a NameError. However, in this code the obj is never ran so no error occurs.

discussion.content: yield keyword expression is I (capital i), while for loop variable is i (small I). Function is erroneous.

>>> def f(n):
... for i in range (1,n+1):
... yield I
...
>>> print(f(2))
<generator object f at 0x0000013BA21A82A0>

ANswer is correct

Selected Answer: C
Selected Answer: C

Selected Answer: B
def f(n):
 for i in range(1,n+1):
 yield i

print(f(2)) #output: <generator object f at 0x000001C77ED4D000>
generator=f(2)
print(next(generator)) #output: 1
print(next(generator)) #output: 2
print(next(generator)) #output: StopIteration

yield control the flow of a generator.
than if we use I instead of the variable name i, it will return an object that represent a generator.
Yield I is not the same as the variable name i. Which should mean runtime error.

Selected Answer: B
The NameError is not raised because the generator is not executed at all. It's defined and only its reference is used. If it is executed in a loop or comprehension or by using next() then only the NameError will be raised.

yield automatically creates, __iter__() and next() function. assuming it was yeild i. 
then to print, we would need print(next(f(2)))

Selected Answer: B
This question is SO TRICKY. yield I, or yield X or yield ANYTHING, doesn't matter because in the code the undefined variable "I" is never reached. As the answer below from TheNetworkStudent, the answer is B.

Selected Answer: C
answer is c because variable names are case sensitive

if you try to loop through the generator, it will error. This won't happen because it's simply printed. Code is erroneous, but won't result in an error if executed in this manner.

questions.question_text:
What will the value of the i variable be when the following loop finishes its execution?
//IMG//

comments.content: Just try to print the value of i after the loop, you would get 9 as result. for i in range(10): pass print(i)

discussion.content: The answer is 9.
9 is the Answer. Pass only means there are no statements to execute it does not means the variable is unavailable. Try a Print statemnt Print(i) after the For Loop and there is your result.

Selected Answer: D. 9

Answers are CD

 pass
print(i)
#output: 9

 print(f"for-i: {i}")

Selected Answer: D

Selected Answer: D
9 in the answer

D is the right answer. The value of the i variable when the for loop finishes its execution will be 9. This is because the range(10) function generates a sequence of numbers from 0 to 9, and the for loop will iterate over this sequence, with the variable i taking on each value in turn. When the for loop reaches the end of the sequence, it will stop, and the value of i at that point will be 9.

If this were run in a function, B would be correct because the value of 'i' does not get returned to the main program; however, if run in the shell, it will return a value of '9' for 'i'. To prove, set i = None prior to the loop, then run the loop, outside the loop print(i) gives value '9'; if the loop is set in a function, regardless of whether the function is run, print(i) would give value 'None'.
